abstract_sentences.1: Informal first-person narratives are a unique resource for computational models of everyday events and people’s affective reactions to them.
abstract_sentences.2: People blogging about their day tend not to explicitly say I am happy.
abstract_sentences.3: Instead they describe situations from which other humans can readily infer their affective reactions.
abstract_sentences.4: However current sentiment dictionaries are missing much of the information needed to make similar inferences.
abstract_sentences.5: We build on recent work that models affect in terms of lexical predicate functions and affect on the predicate’s arguments.
abstract_sentences.6: We present a method to learn proxies for these functions from firstperson narratives.
abstract_sentences.7: We construct a novel fine-grained test set, and show that the patterns we learn improve our ability to predict first-person affective reactions to everyday events, from a Stanford sentiment baseline of .67F to .75F.

body_sentences.2: These narratives provide a rich resource for computational modeling of how people feel about the events they report on.
body_sentences.3: Being able to reliably predict the affect a person may feel towards events they encounter has a range of potential applications, including monitoring mood and mental health (Isaacs et al., 2013) and getting conversational assistants to respond appropriately (Bowden et al., 2017).
body_sentences.4: Moreover, as these narratives are told from the perspective of a protagonist, this research could be used to understand other types of protagonist-framed narratives, like those in fiction.
body_sentences.5: We are interested in the opinions that a protagonist has, not the author per se.
body_sentences.6: This is sometimes referred to as internal sentiment or self reflective sentiment.
body_sentences.7: While in many situations that is overlaid with the author’s opinions, in first-personal narratives, because the author is the protagonist, the two perspectives align.
body_sentences.8: Here, we use the term affect to reference this protagonist-centered notion of opinion.
body_sentences.9: A central obstacle to reliable affect prediction is that that people tend not to explicitly flag their affective state, by saying I am happy.
body_sentences.10: Large-scale sentiment dictionaries focus on compiling lexical items that bear a consistent affect all on their own (Wilson et al., 2005).
body_sentences.11: But people tend to describe situations, such as My friend bought me flowers, or I got a parking ticket, from which other humans can readily infer their implicit affective reactions.
body_sentences.12: One approach to this problem aims to directly learn units larger than a lexical item that reliably bear some marker of polarity or emotion (Vu et al., 2014; Li et al., 2014; Ding and Riloff, 2016; Goyal et al., 2010; Russo et al., 2015; Kiritchenko et al., 2014; Reckman et al., 2013).
body_sentences.13: Another approach aims to model the speaker’s affect to an event compositionally, e.g.

body_sentences.36: 2 Bootstrapping a First-Person Sentiment Corpus  We start with a set of first-person narratives (weblogs) drawn from the Spinn3r corpus, that cover a wide range of topics (Burton et al., 2009; Gordon and Swanson, 2009).
body_sentences.37: To reduce noise, we restrict the blogs to those from well-known blogging sites (Ding and Riloff, 2016), and select 15,466 stories whose length ranges from 225 to 375 words.
body_sentences.38: We hand-annotate a set of 477 positive and 440 negative stories, and use these to bootstrap a larger set of 1,420 negative and 2,288 positive stories.
body_sentences.39: To bootstrap, we apply AutoSlog-TS, a weakly supervised pattern learner that only requires training sets os stories labeled broadly as POSITIVE or NEGATIVE (Riloff, 1996; Riloff and Wiebe, 2003).
body_sentences.40: AutoSlog uses a set of syntactic templates to define different types of linguistic expressions.
body_sentences.41: The left-hand side of Table 3 lists examples of AutoSlog patterns and the right-hand side illustrates a specific lexical-syntactic pattern that corresponds to each general pattern template, as instantiated in first-person stories.1 When bootstrapping a larger positive and negative story corpus, we use the whole story, not just the first person sentences.

body_sentences.44: However, they can also include verb-particle constructions, such as cheated on, or verb-head-of-preposition constructions.
body_sentences.45: In each case though, because these patterns are localized to a verb and only one element, they allow us to learn highly specific patterns that could be incorporated into a dictionary such as +- Effect (Choi and Wiebe, 2014).
body_sentences.46: AutoSlog simultaneously harvests both (syntactically constrained) MWE patterns and more compositionally regular verb-argument groups at the same time.
body_sentences.47: AutoSlog-TS computes statistics on the strength of association of each pattern with each class, i.e.
body_sentences.48: P(POSITIVE | p) and P(NEGATIVE | p), along with the pattern’s overall frequency.
body_sentences.49: We define three parameters for each class: θf , the frequency with which a pattern occurs, θp, the probability with which a pattern is associated with the given class and θn, the number of patterns that must occur in the text for it to be labeled.
body_sentences.50: These parameters are tuned on the dev set (Riloff, 1996; Oraby et al., 2015; Riloff and Wiebe, 2003).
body_sentences.51: To bootstrap a larger corpus, we want settings that have lower recall but very high precision.
body_sentences.52: We select θp = 0.7, θf = 10 and θn = 3 for the positive class and θp = 0.85, θf = 10 and θn = 4 for the negative class for bootstrapping.
body_sentences.53: 3 Experimental Setup  Our experimental setup involves first creating a corpus of training and test sentences, then applying AutoSlog-TS a second time to learn linguistic patterns.
body_sentences.54: We then set up methods for cascading classifiers to explore whether ensemble classifiers improve our results.
body_sentences.55: Training Set: From the bootstrapped set of stories, we create a corpus of sentences.
body_sentences.56: A critical simplifying assumption of our method is that a multi-sentence story can be labelled as a whole as positive or negative, and that each of its sentences inherit this polarity.
body_sentences.57: This means we can learn the polarity of events in such narratives from their (noisy) inherited polarity without labelling individual sentences.
body_sentences.58: Our training set consists of 46,255 positive and 25,069 negative sentences.
body_sentences.59: Test Set: We create the test set by selecting 4k random first-person sentences.
body_sentences.60: First-person sentences either contain an explicit first person marker, i.e.
body_sentences.61: we and my or start with either a progressive verb or pleonastic it.

To collect gold labels, we designed a qualifier and a HIT for Mechanical Turk, and put
these out for annotation by 5 Turkers, who label each instance as positive, negative, or neutral.
body_sentences.63: To ensure the high quality of the test set, we select sentences that were labelled consistently positive or negative by 4 or 5 Turkers.
body_sentences.64: We collected 1,266 positive and 1,440 negative sentences.
body_sentences.65: Dev Set: We created the dev set using the same method as the test set, having Turkers annotate 2k random first-person sentences.
body_sentences.66: We collected 498 positive and 754 negative sentences.
body_sentences.67: The 4k test and dev sentences available for download at https://nlds.soe.ucsc.edu/first-person-sentiment.

body_sentences.72: Our best parameters on the dev set for positive is θf=18, θp=0.85 and θn=1 and for negative is θf=1, θp=0.5 and θn=1.
body_sentences.73: We specify that if the sentence is in both classes we rename it as neutral.
body_sentences.74: We will refer to this classifier as the AutoSlog classifier.
body_sentences.76: Our goal is to see whether the knowledge we learn using AutoSlog-TS complements existing sentiment classifiers.
body_sentences.77: We thus experiment with a number of baseline classifiers: the default SVM classifier from Weka with unigram features (Hall et al., 2005), a version of the NRC-Canada sentiment classifier (Mohammad et al., 2013), provided to us by Qadir and Riloff (2014), and the Stanford Sentiment classifier (Socher et al., 2013).
body_sentences.79: The Stanford Sentiment classifier is a based on Recursive Neural Networks, and trained on a compositional Sentiment Treebank, which includes fine-grained sentiment labels for 215,154 phrases from 11,855 sentences from movie reviews.
body_sentences.80: It can accurately predict some compositional semantic effects and handle negation.
body_sentences.81: However since it was trained on movie reviews, it is likely to be missing labelled data for some common phrases in our blogs.
body_sentences.82: Thus we also retrained it (RETRAINED STANFORD) on high precision phrases from AutoSlog extracted from our training data of positive and negative blogs.
body_sentences.83: This provides 67,710 additional phrases, including 58,972 positive phrases and 8,738 negative phrases.
body_sentences.84: The retrained model includes both the labels from the original Sentiment Treebank and the AutoSlog high precision phrases.
body_sentences.85: 4 Results and Analysis  We present our experimental results and analyze the results in terms of the lexico-functional linguistic patterns we learn.

body_sentences.90: Although AutoSlog itself does not perform highly, the patterns that it learns represent a different type of knowledge than what is contained in many sentiment analysis tools.
body_sentences.91: We therefore hypothesized that a cascading classifier, which supplements one of the baseline sentiment classifiers with the lexicofunctional patterns that AutoSlog learns might yield higher performance.

body_sentences.94: The F-scores for RETRAINED STANFORD are almost identical to the standard Stanford classifier.
body_sentences.95: This may be because our data is a small percentage of the entire number of phrases used in training Stanford.

body_sentences.98: We implement cascading classifiers to test our hypothesis.
body_sentences.99: The cascade classifier has primary and secondary classifiers, and we invoke the secondary classifiers only if the primary assigns a prediction of neutral to a test instance, which reflects the lack of sentimentbearing lexical items.
body_sentences.100: We also have a cascade classifier with a tertiary classifier, which is invoked in the same fashion as the secondary classifier after the primary and secondary classifiers have been run.
body_sentences.101: The cascading classifiers are named in the order the classifier is employed, primary, secondary or primary, secondary, tertiary.
body_sentences.102: For our cascading classifiers, we combine our baseline classifiers (NRC and Stanford), with our AutoSlog classifier.
body_sentences.103: We do not use SVM as a primary classifier since it has no neutral label.
body_sentences.104: The results for the cascading experiments are in Rows 6-9 of Table 4.
body_sentences.105: Cascading NRC and AutoSlog provides the best performance, improving both the positive and negative classes, for a macro F of 0.71.
body_sentences.106: This shows that the learned implicit polarity information from AutoSlog improves NRC’s performance.

Since our best two-classifier cascade comes
from combining NRC and AutoSlog, we also test a cascade that adds Stanford or SVM.
body_sentences.108: We achieve our best macro F of 0.75 for the combination with SVM.
body_sentences.110: Here we discuss how the patterns we learned from AutoSlog can supplement the knowledge encoded in current sentiment classifiers, and in newly evolving sentiment resources (Goyal et al., 2010; Choi and Wiebe, 2014; Balahur et al., 2012; Ruppenhofer and Brandes, 2015).
body_sentences.111: Tables 5 and 6 illustrate several learned lexicofunctional patterns for positive events used in the AutoSlog classifier.
body_sentences.112: The patterns shown in Table 5 are predicted by A&R’s framework, some functions of which can be seen in Table 1.
body_sentences.113: For example, we find a range of basic state descriptions (have party, have cancer) whose basic entailment category is either possessive or property state.
body_sentences.114: Since Ehave is positive for a first-person subject only if the object is positive, and negative if the object is negative, we predict that parties are good to possess and that cancer is a bad property to have.
body_sentences.115: In this way, we can recruit the existing function for have to induce new positive or negative things to “possess.” In line with A&R’s claims, many events are identified with their final results: headed for results in being at a desired location, while not coming home results in something failing to be at a desired location.

We find it a welcome result that our semi-supervised methods
yield patterns that correspond to the A&R classes, thus validating our suspicion that first-person sentences furnish a simplifying test ground for discovering functional patterns in the wild.
body_sentences.117: However, many patterns are not covered by A&R’s general classes, see Table 6.
body_sentences.118: Looking first at verbs, one major correlation is between positive classes and public events and negative classes and private states.
body_sentences.119: Verbs extracted from the positive class tend to be eventive and agentive describing more dynamic activities and interactions, such as played, swim, enjoyed, and danced.
body_sentences.120: Even many positive have uses are light verbs describing an activity such as have lunch.
body_sentences.121: Verbs from the negative class are strikingly different.
body_sentences.122: They are very often stative, where the author is the experiencer (cognitive subject) of that private state.
body_sentences.123: While this state vs. event distinction is not one existing computational models of sentiment or affect discuss explicitly, it replicates a finding that consistently emerges in clinical psychology, one that is explicitly argued for in cognitive-behavioral accounts of the mood that particular activities evoke (Lewinsohn et al., 1985; MacPhillamy and Lewinsohn, 1982; Russo et al., 2015).
body_sentences.124: In addition, Table 6 reveals several novel result state categories.
body_sentences.125: The success, planning, and unmet desire frames are all ultimately about goalfulfillment (or lack thereof).
body_sentences.126: While the success and unmet desire cases could be understood as having or lacking something, the planning cases indicate steps achieved toward a desired end-state.
body_sentences.127: Previous work on learning affect from eventuality descriptions has largely focused on actions.
body_sentences.128: Our results indicate that private state descriptions are another rich source of evidence.

body_sentences.134: Ding and Riloff (2016) extract subj-verb-obj triples from blog posts.
body_sentences.135: They then apply label propagation to spread polarity from sentences to events.
body_sentences.136: However, the triples they learn do not focus on first-person experiencers.
body_sentences.137: They also filter private states out of the verbs used to learn their triples, whereas we have found that verbs relating to private states such as need, want and realize are important indicators of first-person affect.
body_sentences.139: (2012) use the narratives produced by the ISEAR questionnaire (Scherer et al., 1986) for first-person examples of particular emotions and extract sequences of subject-verb-object triples, which they annotate for basic emotions.
body_sentences.140: Recent work has built on this idea, and developed methods to automatically expand Anand & Reschke’s verb classes to create completely new lexical resources (Balahur et al., 2012; Choi and Wiebe, 2014; Deng et al., 2013; Deng and Wiebe, 2014; Ruppenhofer and Brandes, 2015).
body_sentences.141: Choi & Wiebe’s work comes closest to ours in trying to induce (not annotate) lexical functions, but we attempt to infer these from stories directly, whereas they use a structured lexical resource.
body_sentences.142: 6 Conclusion  We show that we can learn lexico-functional linguistic patterns that reliably predict first-person affect.
body_sentences.143: We constructed a dataset of positive and negative first-person experiencer sentences and used them to learn such patterns.
body_sentences.144: We then showed that the performance of current sentiment classifiers can be enhanced by augmenting them with these patterns.
body_sentences.145: By adding our AutoSlog classifier’s results to existing classifiers we were able to improve from a baseline 0.67 to 0.75 Macro F with a cascading classifier of NRC, AutoSlog and SVM.
body_sentences.146: In addition, we analyze the linguistic functions that indicate positivity and negativity for the first person experiencer, and show that they are very different.
body_sentences.147: In first-person descriptions, positivity is often signaled by active participations in events, while negativity involves private states.
body_sentences.148: In future work, we plan to explore the integration of these observations into sentiment resources such as the +-Effect lexicon (Choi and Wiebe, 2014).
body_sentences.149: We plan to apply these high precision first-person lexical patterns beyond blog data and with other personmarking.
